– BP's next CEO Bob Dudley says the company's compensation for the Deepwater Horizon oil spill will probably be less than $20 billion, the Wall Street Journal reports.
– The Deepwater Horizon oil spill has knocked BP out of the world's 100 best brands for the first time in 11 years, according to a leading marketing consultancy.

– The final plug in the blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico. The US government officially declared the well "dead" today after pumping in cement to seal the well. The Wall Street Journal reports that BP's shares rose sharply in after-hours trading.
– The White House office for management and budget blocked scientists seeking permission to model the Gulf oil spill two weeks after the explosion of the BP's Deepwater Horizon oil rig.

– BP CEO Bob Dudley told the Confederation of British Industry today that the company will not be quitting the US. “We are not going to quit America,” Dudley told the Confederation of British Industry.
– The Coast Guard diver was killed in the Deepwater Horizon explosion. The Coast Guard has officially identified the victim as one of the one of the Deepwater Horizon explosion.
– The oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is now the largest oil spill in US history, according to the Wall Street Journal. The spill was caused by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

– The presidential inquiry into the Deepwater Horizon oil spill has found no evidence that BP and other oil companies put profits ahead of safety, according to the Wall Street Journal. The inquiry also found that BP, Halliburton, and TransOcean neglected safety during the oil spill, according to the Los Angeles Times.
– Click here for the latest from the Boston Marathon Boston's Marathon finished for the Boston Marathon finished for the Boston Marathon to raise money to raise awareness.

– The state of Alaska has hit BP with a $1 million fine for the company's role in a 2006 oil spill. The state last week slapped the company with a $1 million fine for not responding to safety warnings about a broken pipeline, reports the Anchorage Daily News.

– BP's damage estimates for the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Kenneth Feinberg, the administrator of BP's oil spill victims compensation fund, says he will only pay out 2.3 billion dollars to victims of the oil spill, according to the Wall Street Journal.

– The White House released its report on the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The report says BP's oil spill could have been avoided if the oil company had heeded warnings about the dangers of the Macondo well, according to the Wall Street Journal.

– The Justice Department's lawsuit against BP has exposed the company to billions in legal costs. BP shares fell 3% at the start of trading in London today. The suit seeks "unlimited damages" to cover the costs of cleaning up the oil, the losses suffered by local businesses, and the damage done to the environment.
– The Justice Department's long-awaited report on the Deepwater Horizon. The report is expected to be "utterly damning," according to the Wall Street Journal.

– The Coast Guard is searching the Gulf of Mexico for 11 workers missing in the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig. The rig, which exploded yesterday, was drilling an 18,000-foot well, the New York Times reports. The blowout preventer was not working as it should have, according to the Coast Guard, which is investigating the cause of the explosion.

– BP's first-quarter net profits doubled from a year earlier, to $5.3 billion, but the company's shares dropped 7% as investors worried about the size of the Gulf oil spill and the company's ability to pay it, the Wall Street Journal reports. BP said it will set up a $20 billion compensation fund for victims of the spill, and it will sell off assets to pay for it, the Telegraph reports.

– Louisiana shrimpers have filed the first class-action lawsuit against BP and other defendants in the Gulf oil spill, Reuters reports. The suit names BP, TransOcean, and Halliburton, and was filed on behalf of “all coastal Louisiana interests.” It also names the federal government, the states of Louisiana and Mississippi, and the fishing industry. Click here for more.

– BP's chief executive says the company will not enforce the terms of contracts it has with fishermen helping clean up the Gulf of Mexico. The contracts, which the Alabama attorney general says were "arbitrary and deceptive," waive BP's right to sue the fishermen for damages caused by the spill, the New York Times reports. The contracts also state that BP will pay the fishermen's legal fees. The attorney general's office says it will investigate the allegations. The contracts were offered to Alabama fishermen in the wake of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, and the fishermen say they were told they could help clean up the Gulf for up to five years if they signed the contracts.

– The scope of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is just beginning to become clear, and the Obama administration is ramping up efforts to contain it. The White House has asked BP and other companies involved in the spill to provide details on their emergency response plans, reports the Wall Street Journal. Brazil, meanwhile, has asked oil companies operating offshore fields to provide information on well control systems and to review their emergency response protocols. Click here for more.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil spilling in the Gulf of Mexico has hit a snag. The company says it will take 48 hours to assess the problem, which is the formation of hydrates, or flammable ice, near the leak site, reports the Times-Picayune of New Orleans. It's not clear whether the hydrates are the cause of the problem, notes the Wall Street Journal. BP also said in a statement that the spill cost it 350 million dollars so far.

– The blowout preventer that triggered the massive oil spill off the Louisiana coast was not designed to withstand the force of an underwater gusher, a blowout preventer expert tells the New York Times. The blowout preventer was originally designed to withstand a 7,500-foot-deep gusher, but the pressure inside the blowout preventer was too great for that, the expert says. The blowout preventer has now been re-engineered to withstand a much larger spill, the Times reports.

– The Obama administration's latest estimate of the size of the Gulf oil spill is far too low, according to Thad Allen, the head of the Coast Guard's oil spill response team. The Coast Guard estimates that between 500,000 and 800,000 barrels of oil have been spilled so far, a far cry from the 1 million to 4 million barrels BP says are likely to be in the Gulf by the end of the week. "The estimates that we have are far too low," Allen tells the New York Times. "We have to do a better job with the information that we have." The Coast Guard believes the true size of the spill is closer to 1 million barrels. BP, meanwhile, said yesterday that the hydrates, which form in oil and gas hydrates, had hydrates on their way to the surface, not at the well, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil spill has so far only succeeded in siphoning about a fifth of the oil flowing into the Gulf, but the company says it may be able to stop the flow permanently within a week, reports the Wall Street Journal. The news comes as BP's share price continues to plunge.

– BP's latest progress in containing the oil spilling in the Gulf of Mexico was siphoned off a mile below the surface, the New York Times reports. The two-mile-long tube was placed over the pipe late yesterday in an effort to collect the oil, but it took longer than expected to get to the surface because of the size of the pipe. The tube will be used to suck the oil back to the surface, where it will be placed on a tanker. The full size of the spill will take up to two weeks, and it will be the biggest in US history, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– The feds are going to make BP pay for the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, a top official tells the New York Times. The official said that the feds will “absolutely” fine the company if it doesn’t do enough to contain the oil and clean up the environmental mess. BP insisted that it was doing all it could to contain the spill, but the government’s message to the company yesterday was clear: “There is no magic fix for the oil spill that looks like curdled chocolate milk flowing on top of the Gulf of Mexico.” Click here for more.

– BP's latest attempt to plug the gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico didn't work out so well, and the company will have to repeat the procedure thousands of times over, the Wall Street Journal reports. The procedure, known as a "top kill," involves pumping mud into the well, but it's not clear whether it will work. It's the first time BP has tried this tactic since the Deepwater Horizon disaster, and it will likely be at least a week before engineers know for sure whether it will work. Meanwhile, the Coast Guard has confirmed that the blowout preventer was not working properly, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports.

– BP's latest attempt to plug an oil well in the Gulf of Mexico didn't work, and the company's chief operating officer said today that the company will move on to another option, Reuters reports. "We have not been able to stop the flow," Doug Suttles said. "We have made the decision to move on to the next option." The development comes as BP stock plunged in the wake of the company's failure to plug the well in five days.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the Gulf oil spill didn't work out so well, and the company's CEO, Tony Hayward, is out of a job, the Wall Street Journal reports. Hayward will be replaced by COO Bob Dudley, and the company will set up a $20 billion compensation fund for victims. Meanwhile, BP shares rose slightly in early trading. Click here for more on the company's latest efforts to contain the oil.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil spilling in the Gulf of Mexico appears to be working, the company said today. It captured 10,500 barrels, or about 439,950 gallons, in 24 hours, and a second containment system should be in place within 24 hours, the company said. But that's not good enough, and President Obama warned today that the company shouldn't pay " nickel and dime" for damage claims. "My understanding is that BP has contracted for $ 50 million worth of TV advertising to manage their image during the course of this disaster," he said. Click here for more.

– President Obama says he wants to know “whose ass to kick” over the Gulf oil spill, adding to the pressure on energy giant BP as it sought to capture more of the leak from its gushing well. In an interview with NBC News, Obama also said that if BP Chief Executive Tony Hayward worked for him, he would have fired him by now over his response to the 50 years-old spill, the worst environmental disaster in US history. The British company's stock price plunged to a 14 year low in US trading, reports the Wall Street Journal.

– BP's share price has plunged 40% in the wake of the Gulf oil spill, and analysts believe the damage could be many times greater than the spill itself. The stock hit a record low of $44.53 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, reports the Wall Street Journal. BP's market value has fallen to $35 billion, and analysts believe the company will need to raise $32 billion in order to cover the cost of the spill. British Prime Minister David Cameron defended the oil giant today, notes Reuters, saying, "This is not the time to be belittling BP."

– President Obama will press BP executives this week to set up an escrow account to pay damage claims by individuals and businesses hurt by the Gulf oil spill disaster. The move comes as Obama, who will address the nation about the spill on Tuesday night, faces questions on his handling of the disaster, which was in its 55th day State officials say they are feeling the effects, both environmentally and financially, and that they need much more than what BP is offering to recover lost wages and taxes. It's partly political posturing, but there's a real threat, too Setting the stage for a showdown with BP executives at congressional hearings this week, two Democratic lawmakers said the British company chose faster and cheaper drilling options in the Gulf of Mexico that increased the danger of a catastrophic well failure.

– BP CEO Carl Svanberg apologized to the American people for the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico today during a White House meeting with President Obama. “We are deeply sorry for what has happened,” Svanberg said, adding that the company will set up a $20 billion fund to pay the spill, the New York Times reports. “We will pay the claims of every American who has been affected by the oil spill,” he said. “We will pay for the cleanup, we will pay the claims of every American who has lost a job because of the oil spill, and we will compensate every American who has suffered from the effects of the oil spill.”

– BP CEO Tony Hayward was spotted watching a yacht race off the English coast Saturday, sparking new controversy in the United States as his company struggles to plug its huge Gulf of Mexico oil spill. A spokeswoman for the British energy giant, said Hayward was spending time with his teenage son at the Isle of Wight boat race after devoting most of the past two months to the oil spill away from his family GRAND ISLE, Louisiana—Those on the front lines of the Gulf Coast oil spill say they are forced to fight two battles—one against the crude washing into lush wetlands and another against needless bureaucracy. – BP's latest estimate of the amount of oil it's spilling into the Gulf of Mexico is about 100,000 barrels a day, or about two-and-a-half times the amount the company said it would take to clean up the spill, reports the Wall Street Journal. The figure is based on the company's estimate yesterday of 5,000 barrels a day, which it now says would be siphoned off via a tanker. BP also resumed efforts to siphon the oil today after halting them yesterday for 10 hours due to a fire onboard the containment system, notes the New York Times.

– House Democrats are working on legislation to tighten rules on deep-water drilling, especially in the wake of the BP oil spill, Rep. Henry Waxman tells Reuters. “We’re working on it,” he said. Waxman, the top Democrat on the House Energy and Commerce panel, says the legislation will likely include new regulations on the oil industry, as well as measures to prevent a repeat of the Deepwater Horizon disaster, the New York Times reports.

– One of New Orleans’ most prominent and highly regarded chefs has sued BP for damages to restaurants that have lost normal seafood supplies because of the Gulf oil spill. Susan Spicer, who runs the restaurant Bayona in the French Quarter, is seeking class-action status on behalf of restaurants and others in the seafood industry that have suffered damage since the April 20 explosion of the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig. Meanwhile, BP said it has spent 300 million dollars in the last three days alone on cleanup efforts, bringing its total bill to 2.65 billion dollars so far, reports Reuters.

– Tropical storm Alex slowed oil spill clean-up work in the Gulf of Mexico and drove more petroleum into fragile Gulf wetlands and beaches on Thursday, with any permanent fix to BP's ruptured deep-sea well still several weeks away. More than 10 weeks into the crisis, oil continued spewing into the Gulf, clean-up success remained limited, and a proposal by the Obama administration to halt all deep-water drilling for the next six months remained in limbo, reports Reuters.

– New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo has signed a bill that will make fracking legal in the state, the New York Daily News reports. The bill, which was signed by Cuomo on Friday, makes New York the first state in the nation to legalize the practice, according to the Wall Street Journal. Gov. Andrew Cuomo signed the bill on the same day that he declared a state of emergency in response to the fracking crisis in the state.

– BP hopes to have the Gulf oil spill under control by July 27, ahead of its earlier target of mid-August, the Wall Street Journal reports, citing company officials. The July 27 target date is the day the company is due to report second-quarter earnings and will speak to investors. Meanwhile, BP dampened hopes that it could plug its leaking Gulf of Mexico well sooner than forecast on Thursday, while a battle between the US BP aims to fix leaking oil well by July 27. – The BP oil spill is already killing birds, and one of the worst was a harmless spill that killed more than 60,000 long-tailed ducks. The spill from a ship in the Baltic Sea in 1976 was one of the worst for birds, according to a study in the journal Nature. The study also identified two previously unknown species of bottom—dwelling fish in the Gulf of Mexico, living right in the area affected by the BP oil spill. Meanwhile, BP said it had made progress on a new system to capture most of the oil, and that a relief well could be used to plug the leak by mid-August.

– BP's new containment cap was able to slow the flow of oil into the Gulf of Mexico for the first time in more than three months yesterday. The company said that during a pressure test, it closed three of five valves on the cap, reports the Wall Street Journal. – Kenneth Feinberg, the administrator of BP’s $20 billion compensation fund for victims of the Gulf oil spill, says the company is holding up payments. “I have a concern that BP is stalling claims,” Feinberg tells the New York Times. “We’re not waiting for BP to be able to plug the well.” Meanwhile, the Times reports that Adjusters passing out emergency funds in Louisiana and other Gulf Coast states are on high alert for fraud, even as they pay out legitimate claims. Swindlers, scammers, and even a few strippers are flocking to the Gulf Coast in search of a piece of the $20 billion BP has set aside to compensate residents for spill-related losses.

– BP's new CEO, Bob Dudley, says the company will set up a $20 billion fund to compensate victims of the Gulf oil spill. Dudley, who was appointed yesterday, says the money will come from BP's shareholders, not from the federal government, the Wall Street Journal reports. He also said the company will set up a compensation fund for injured workers and small businesses. The announcement comes a day after BP said it would set up a $20 billion fund to pay for the spill.

– The BP oil spill has put a major wrench in Norway’s plans to open up more of its Arctic waters to oil and gas drilling. The delay will give scientists time to assess the effects of the spill. – BP's chief executive says the cost of the Gulf oil spill is likely to be much higher than the $4.5 billion the company originally planned to pay, reports the Wall Street Journal. Bob Dudley told a Senate panel yesterday that the damage bill will likely be much higher than the $4.5 billion the company originally planned to pay. "It's going to be much higher than that," he said. "It's going to be a bill that we have to live with for the rest of our life." The British oil giant has agreed to set up a $20 billion fund to pay victims of the spill.

– The "dead zone" at the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico has now covered 7,722 square miles—the size of Massachusetts—and overlaps areas hit by oil from BP's broken Macondo well, scientists say. The area of hypoxia, or low levels of oxygen, covered 20,000 square miles and extended far into Texas waters, according to researchers from the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium. – Alabama is suing BP, Transocean, and Halliburton for “catastrophic harm” caused by the Gulf oil spill, the state’s attorney general announced today. The lawsuit, which names BP, Transocean, and Halliburton as defendants, will be filed in a federal court in New Orleans, the Wall Street Journal reports. The state is seeking damages for lost tourism, economic losses, medical expenses, and more. The suit will also allow Alabama to join other states suing BP for damages.

– The extent of the BP oil spill's impact on the Gulf of Mexico is still unknown, but a 22-mile-long plume of what is believed to be oil and chemical dispersants has already reached the surface, the New York Times reports. The Deepwater Horizon rig was drilling five miles below the surface when it exploded on April 20, killing 11 workers and setting off the spill.

– The damage from the BP oil spill is still visible in the Gulf of Mexico, but scientists say that's because the oil has been eaten by microscopic organisms. The micro-organisms were apparently stimulated by the spill, and they degraded the hydrocarbons so efficiently that the plume is now undetectable, said Terry Hazen of the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. The organisms were apparently stimulated by the massive oil spill that began in April, and they degraded the hydrocarbons so efficiently that the plume is now undetectable, said Hazen. Click here for more.

– BP CEO Tony Hayward will be grilled by British lawmakers next week over the Gulf oil spill, as part of an investigation into the risks involved in deepwater drilling in the North Sea. British Members of Parliament will next week grill Hayward as part of an investigation into risks around deepwater drilling in the North Sea, reports Reuters. Meanwhile, BP said it will delay its third-quarter results due to the challenges of accounting for spill costs.

– BP's compensation plan for the Gulf oil spill probably won't cost the company as much as previously thought, analysts say. The company believes claims will be less than the $20 billion it has set up for an independent claims fund, the Wall Street Journal reports. BP's new CEO, Bob Dudley, who takes over next month, met with analysts yesterday, according to Citigroup, which estimates the fund will probably exceed calls for claims.

– BP CEO Tony Hayward is taking heat from British lawmakers who want to know more about the company's preparedness in the wake of the Gulf oil spill. “It’s been easy for some parties to suggest that this is a problem with BP,” Hayward told a parliamentary committee, according to Reuters. “It’s been easy for some members of parliament to suggest that this is a problem with BP.” Hayward, who was grilled by the committee for more than two hours, said the spill was the result of “fundamental” safety flaws, not BP’s cost-cutting efforts, the Telegraph reports.

– The final shot of cement in BP's Gulf of Mexico oil spill well was fired early this morning, sending a plume of oil into the sea. The remotely operated vehicle (ROV) was used to fire the final shot, around 4am EDT, said a spokesman for BP. The spokesman said the cement was placed in the well at 5,000 feet below the surface, reports Reuters. The ROV will continue to monitor the well for days.

– The oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico will have little or no effect on the medium-term outlook for offshore drilling and supplies, the International Energy Agency tells Reuters. The IEA, a branch of the International Energy Agency, is the world's leading energy watchdog. The US Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation, and Enforcement is the federal agency in charge of the Gulf's offshore drilling.

– The White House and BP are close to a deal on how much money the oil giant will have to pay for the Gulf oil spill, the Wall Street Journal reports. Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, and Florida will likely get the biggest chunk of the money, with Texas and Louisiana getting the least. The states will likely also get some money from BP's fund for expenses related to the spill. Meanwhile, BP's incoming CEO, Bob Dudley, has promised a major overhaul of the company's operations in the wake of the spill, the BBC reports.

– Cancer rates in the Gulf of Mexico are “astronomically high” as they’ve ever been since the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, according to a new study. The researchers, who tested samples taken off the coast of Louisiana just weeks after the spill, found that levels of five cancer-causing chemicals were “astonishingly high” as they’d been before the spill, the New York Times reports. The cancer rates were even higher than they’d been before the spill, according to an Oregon State University researcher who’s one of the lead authors of the study, which will be published in the October issue of the American Journal of Public Health. The researchers say they’re not sure why the cancer rates are so high, but they’re not the first to find them in the Gulf.

– The world's biggest-ever study of marine life has wrapped up, with 2,700 scientists from 80 countries finding more than 10,000 new species, reports the BBC. The $665 million, 10-year study will help scientists assess the health of the world's oceans, as well as the effects of climate change, BP's oil spill, and other threats. Among the discoveries: a giant squid that measures 23 feet long, the world's longest known species of sea creature.

– The White House “ relied too much on BP” in the wake of the Gulf oil spill, according to a report released today by the National Oil Spill Commission. The report found that the administration was “overly optimistic” about BP’s ability to handle the spill, and that the company blocked government spill estimates that might have prompted quicker action, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– Royal Dutch Shell CEO Peter Voser is not a fan of BP’s latest report on the Gulf oil spill, which he says focuses too much on the design of the well and not enough on the thinking behind it, the Wall Street Journal reports. “The BP report focuses too much on the design of the well, and not enough on the thinking behind the well,” Voser said at an Oil and Money conference in London yesterday. “This is not a perfect report, but it is a good report.” BP’s report focused on the design of the well, not the thinking behind it, Voser said, adding that Shell would be willing to work with BP to improve the design.

– BP has decided to waive the legal cap on its liability for the Gulf oil spill, a move that will allow it to pay far less in clean-up costs than it would have if it had stuck to the legal limit. The company said in a court filing that it had decided to waive the statutory limitation on liability under the Tort Claims Act, which could have limited its liability to about $75 million, the Wall Street Journal reports. "BP has chosen to waive the statutory limitation on liability under OPA," the company said in the filing.

– BP's efforts to contain the Gulf oil spill have hit a snag: The blowout preventer that was supposed to be attached to the well has failed, the New York Times reports. The blowout preventer has been removed from the wellhead, but the blowout preventer itself will not be removed until a relief well is completed, which could take up to three months. The news comes as BP has agreed to set up a command center in New Orleans to oversee the cleanup. The agreement also calls for BP to pay all costs related to the spill, and for the federal government to pay any costs not covered by the agreement, the AP reports.

– BP's new CEO has a message for critics who blame the Gulf oil spill on the company's safety culture: It's time to "get out of the business." Bob Dudley said rivals and the media had a hand in causing a "climate of fear" during the spill, Reuters reports. "We have to get out of the business of blaming others," he said. "We have to get out of the business of blaming others for the failure of our equipment. We have to get out of the business of blaming others for the failure of our people." The comments come as BP sold four Gulf fields to Japan's Marubeni Corp for 650 million dollars. The company has agreed to sell up to 30 billion dollars' worth of assets to pay for the spill.

– Halliburton used flawed cement in BP's doomed Gulf of Mexico well, which could have contributed to the blowout that sparked the worst offshore oil spill in US history, according to documents obtained by the Wall Street Journal. The documents show that Halliburton, BP's primary contractor on the well, used cement that was "poorly formulated" and didn't last as long as usual in the event of a blowout, the New York Times reports. The cement was made byHalliburton predecessor cementing company Halliburton Co., which was bought by BP last year. BP said in a statement that it has confirmed that the cement was used in the well.

– BP raised its estimate of the cost of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill to 40 billion dollars today, as it reported a third-quarter loss of $4.5 billion. The British oil giant said it will pay the spill cost in full by the middle of next year, reports the Wall Street Journal. The company also said it will sell off four of its stake in the well, a move that will save it about $1.5 billion a year, according to the Financial Times.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the Gulf oil spill has hit a snag: The blowout preventer that was supposed to be at the center of the operation failed to work properly, the New York Times reports. The blowout preventer, which was supposed to be attached to the venting system that was supposed to shut off the oil flow into the Gulf, was not working properly, according to BP's latest estimates. The Times notes that the blowout preventer has now been repaired, but that the damage to the venting system will take a long time to fix.

– The White House's oil spill commission released preliminary findings today that largely blame BP's equipment for the Gulf oil spill, reports the Wall Street Journal. Among the findings: The blowout preventer didn't work properly, the cement in the well wasn't properly tested, and the blowout preventer's annular space didn't isolate hydrocarbons. Bobby Jindal, who has a new book out on the spill, accused the White House of "political posturing" and a "lackadaisical" response, notes the New Orleans Times-Picayune.

– The Justice Department’s report on the BP oil spill is out, and it doesn’t sound pretty. The report concludes that BP and its partners made “critical errors” that led to the largest offshore oil spill in US history, reports the Wall Street Journal. The report also calls for the revoking of BP’s probation in Alaska in the wake of the 2006 Prudhoe Bay pipeline spill, because the company continued to be “negligent” even after pleading guilty. Click here for more.

– The administrator of BP Plc's $20 billion fund for victims of the worst US oil spill says the money won't go to the victims directly, but will instead go to victims' relatives. Kenneth Feinberg, who was appointed by President Obama to oversee the spill, tells the Wall Street Journal that the money will go not to the victims themselves, but to relatives of victims or their loved ones who were affected by the spill. He says the fund will be set up so that victims can make claims even if they live more than 100 miles from the site of the spill. The Journal notes that Feinberg's announcement comes a day after BP said it would set up its own fund for victims.

– BP's new chief executive Bob Dudley said the company was “comfortable” with the size of the damage caused by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, and that it would “absolutely” pay for the damage. “We’re comfortable with the size of the spill,” he told reporters in London, according to the Telegraph. “We’ll pay for the damage. We’ll pay for the cost of the cleanup, we’ll pay for the damage to the Gulf of Mexico, but we’ll also pay for the long-term interests of the company.” Dudley, who took over from Tony Hayward last week, said the company would “absolutely” pay for the damage caused by the spill. BP’s shares rose more than 2% in early trading on the news.

– The White House oil spill commission said today that BP told them the government's final estimate of the amount of oil flowing from the Deepwater Horizon well was about 20% to 50% too high. The White House oil spill commission released the comments today in the wake of a closed-door meeting with BP execs, the Wall Street Journal reports. The company told them the government's estimate of 53,400 and 60,000 barrels per day was too low.

– The Obama administration’s claim that BP made “breathtakingly inept” decisions in the face of the Gulf oil spill is just the tip of the iceberg, according to an investigative report by the New York Times. The Times says BP made “a series of decisions that were breathtakingly inept” and that the administration should have done more to prevent the spill. The report, commissioned by the White House and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, also accuses BP of misleading the public about the size of the spill and the cost of cleanup. The administration’s claim that only tarballs and sheen had reached the Gulf was “highly misleading,” according to the report, because the tarballs were nowhere near the size of the spill and the sheen was nowhere near the size of the spill. Meanwhile, Helix Energy Solutions Group is building a system of vessels and equipment that could be used to respond to a future deepwater oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the company said yesterday.

– The Department of Homeland Security has issued a warning to Americans not to travel to parts of the Middle East and North Africa in the wake of al-Qaeda's attack on the US consulate in Benghazi, Libya. The warning, issued by the department's National Counterterrorism Center, says travelers should avoid areas of the region where attacks have occurred, especially Libya, Syria, and Yemen, the AP reports. The warning was issued after attacks on the US consulate and the US Embassy in Libya that killed Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans.

– The Dow's five-day winning streak came to an end yesterday, with the Dow falling 83 points to 10,811, reports MarketWatch. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also fell. The Dow's five-day winning streak is the longest since a six-day winning streak in late 2007, notes the Wall Street Journal.

– The world's top three insurance brokers have teamed up to offer a joint insurance scheme to cover the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the Financial Times reports. Munich Re, Aon Benfield, and Lloyd's of London will offer up to $1 billion in liability insurance for companies involved in the Deepwater Horizon drilling project, which has already caused the biggest-ever oil spill in the Gulf. The scheme, called SOSCover, will cover up to $20 billion in damages and will be offered to companies involved in the drilling, the Financial Times notes.

– Stephen Baldwin and a friend are suing Costner's company for scamming them into selling their shares, reports the Hollywood Reporter. Costner's company, CINC, claimed to have developed a technology that separated oil from water. The suit says Baldwin and friend Spyridon Contogouris were duped into selling their shares in the company.

– The White House's long-awaited report on the Gulf oil spill is out, and it blames both BP and TransOcean for the disaster, reports the Wall Street Journal. BP will get the lion's share of the blame, with TransOcean getting the lion's share of the slack. The report concludes that both companies made major errors that led to the disaster, but BP will get the lion's share of the money to clean up the mess. TransOcean will get the lion's share of the money to pay spill-related claims, but BP will get the lion's share of the money to set up a fund to pay claims. The full report is here.

– The Washington Post is out with a piece on BP's massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, and it's not good news for the oil giant. The story quotes Christine Bader, who worked for BP from 1999 to 2008 and was one of the first female employees of a major oil company, as saying that the spill was caused by a "horrendous mix of hubris, incompetent decision-making, and a failure to recognize the full extent of the damage that had been done to the environment and to the people of the Gulf Coast." Bader says she was told by a BP executive that the spill was caused by a "rigorous" environmental assessment process, and that the company should have done more to prevent it. She says she was told that BP would pay for the cleanup, and that the government would pay for the cleanup itself. The Post says the story is based on anonymous sources, and that it has reached out to BP for comment. The company has not responded.

– The co-chairs of the White House oil spill commission made their case for legislation to prevent a repeat of last year's massive BP oil spill at two congressional hearings today. Democrats pressed for new legislation aimed at preventing a repeat of last year's massive BP oil spill, as Republicans warned that the disaster should not be used to hamper offshore oil and natural gas production. The renewed push to boost government oversight of offshore drilling came as the co-chairs of the White House oil spill commission, Bill Reilly and Bob Graham, made their case for legislation on the issue at two separate congressional hearings.

– Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal has signed an executive order to speed up the cleanup of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, the New York Times reports. The order, which still needs to be signed by the president, calls for the creation of a task force to figure out how to speed up the cleanup and make sure it's safe for workers and the public. Jindal's order also calls for the creation of a fund to pay for the cleanup, and for state and local officials to help pay for it.

– The blowout preventer that failed to stop the Deepwater Horizon oil spill had a dead battery, leaks in its hydraulic system, and a "test version" of a key component that wasn't strong enough to cut through steel joints in the well pipe and stop the flow of oil, a House investigation has found. The report, which BP says is the first comprehensive look at the blowout preventer's design, also found that the blowout preventer was never adequately tested, the New York Times reports. "It's hard to overstate how devastating this report is," said Rep. Pete Olson, chair of the House Energy and Commerce Committee investigation. "This device was supposed to be a fail-safe, and it was a failure."

– BP's plan to suck up all the oil from the gushing well in the Gulf of Mexico in the next three months has so far been a bust. The company has been unable to stop the flow of oil into the Gulf, and it will take at least another three months to plug the well, the New York Times reports. The company says it has spent about $50 million so far on cleanup efforts, and it plans to spend another $150 million over the next six months. The money will go to state and local governments to help pay for cleanup, and it will also help the company pay for a cost-of-living adjustment for workers and their families, who have been affected by the oil spill. The Times notes that BP's estimate of 5,000 barrels of oil a day could be low given the current rate of damage to the Gulf.

– The Coast Guard has deployed 11 ships to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. The ships are armed with remotely operated vehicles that can stop the flow of oil, and the Coast Guard has set up a command center in New Orleans to monitor the spill, the paper notes. The spill is already the biggest in the region's history.

– The Coast Guard has told BP to intensify efforts to contain the growing oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The Coast Guard has told BP to intensify efforts to contain the spill, which is expected to reach Louisiana's delicate coastline by tonight, 24 hours ahead of a Coast Guard projection earlier in the day, reports the Times-Picayune. Gov. Bobby Jindal met with Interior Secretary Ken Salazar today, notes the Washington Post.

– BP's chief executive will testify before a Senate panel today about the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the Washington Post reports. Other execs from the company and TransOcean, the owner of the rig that exploded, will also appear before the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee. Click here for more on the spill.

– BP's chief executive will testify before a Senate panel today about the company's handling of the Gulf oil spill, the New York Times reports. Other execs will include the head of Halliburton, BP's partner in the Deepwater Horizon rig, and the head of Transocean, which owns the sunken oil rig. The full list of witnesses is here.

– BP finally began siphoning oil from the gushing well in the Gulf of Mexico today, in what the Los Angeles Times calls a “rare bulletin of good news about 31/2 weeks into the crisis.” The company began by inserting a tube into a leaking pipe, and began siphoning some of the oil to a drilling rig at the surface. The deep-sea plumbing did not do anything to close the well, and a substantial amount of oil continues to leak at the bottom of the gulf, but the day’s efforts were a rare bulletin of good news about 31/2 weeks into the crisis.

– The White House has announced the creation of an independent commission to investigate the Deepwater Horizon oil spill. Current and former federal officials will not be on the panel, which will be similar in scope to those that investigated the space shuttle Challenger explosion and the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island, reports the Washington Post. The announcement comes as BP continued to siphon some of the oil gushing from a damaged well on the Gulf floor but remained days away from trying to cap the leak. A tide of sludgy oil has begun washing into the fringes of Louisiana's coastal marshes, officials said today, as BP continued to siphon some of the oil gushing from a damaged well on the gulf floor but remained days away from trying to cap the leak. Watch the oil spill's path since May 2 and view how tourism, commerce and the coastline are all at risk.

– The Coast Guard has found at least 11 injured or dead animals in the Gulf of Mexico so far from the BP oil spill, reports the Times-Picayune. The animals include birds, sea turtles, fish, mammals, and reptiles. The extent of the damage to wildlife is still unknown, but officials fear that many of the injured and dead animals are going undiscovered because of the oil spill, notes the Washington Post.

– The blowout preventer at the site of the Gulf oil spill has been removed, the New York Times reports. The blowout preventer has been taken out by Transocean, the blowout preventer's owner, and BP will take over the cleanup operation. BP will also take over the costs of the cleanup operation, which will be shared by the federal government and the oil company, the Wall Street Journal reports. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar said yesterday that he was "angry and I am frustrated" that BP hadn't been able to seal its blown-out oil well.

– The Coast Guard has told BP to fire when ready with its so-called "top kill" plan, reports the New York Times. The idea is to pump mud into the gushing well to plug it, a practice that has worked on land but never been tried at the ocean's surface. The Coast Guard has told BP to fire when ready with its so-called "top kill" plan, reports the Times. The live video of the spill can be seen here. The Coast Guard has told BP to fire when ready with its so-called "top kill" plan. The live video of the spill can be seen here. – BP's latest attempt to plug its oil well in the Gulf of Mexico didn't work out so well today, and the company will have to repeat the procedure thousands of times over the next few days. The live video feed of the "top kill" operation, which had been expected to last at least 24 hours, didn't work, reports the Washington Post. The live video feed, which is expected to last at least 24 hours, is here.

– The White House has distanced itself from BP in the wake of the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, and it's doing so in a way that smacks of caving to pressure from the oil giant, reports the Washington Post. President Obama has told his attorney general to "prosecute the responsible party in the most vigorously possible way," notes the New York Times. The move comes as the company's share price nosedived in the wake of the spill.

– The White House has ordered BP to pay for the creation of five more large sections of Louisiana barrier island sand berms in the Gulf of Mexico, the New York Times reports. The berms will help slow the spread of the oil, which has already closed oyster beds, shut down shrimpers, and canceled fishing tournaments, and is threatening the beaches of Louisiana, Florida, and Mississippi. The White House has also ordered BP to pay for the costs of the spill cleanup, according to the Washington Post.

– The oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is still expected to take at least a month to clean up, and the New Orleans Times-Picayune takes a look at some of the potential environmental damage it could cause. The bottom of the Gulf, for instance, is a popular destination for fishermen, and the effects of the spill on the area's marine life could be devastating. It's not clear how much oil is in the water, but the best guess is that it's somewhere between 10,000 and 20,000 barrels a day. The Times-Picayune also takes a look at BP's internal investigations, which show that the company ignored safety and environmental rules and risked a "serious accident" if it didn't change its ways.

– BP's stock price took a nosedive today as the company announced plans to erect a device to capture most of the oil coming out of the Deepwater Horizon well. The stock price of BP plunged more than 15% today to a 14-year low as the amount of oil spewing out of the Deepwater Horizon well is substantially greater than the company or the federal government initially estimated. Coast Guard Adm Before the spill, the Obama administration lifted the moratorium on drilling in U.S Why is oil spill hard to predict? Look to the clouds. – BP CEO Tony Hayward arrived at the White House today for a one-on-one meeting with President Obama, after the company agreed to set up a $20 billion escrow fund to pay victims of the Gulf oil spill. The meeting comes as the US accepted Canada's offer of 9,842 feet of oil-skimming boom, the New York Times reports. The US has received offers of state-of-the-art oil-skimming equipment from other countries, but the Obama administration saw no need to accept them.

– The much-anticipated BP-Obama showdown at the White House turned into "no-nonsense business meeting," writes Michael Grunwald for Time. The oil giant agreed to set up a $20 billion escrow account to pay spill claims, and CEO Tony Hayward offered a single-word apology. "I am deeply sorry," he said. "It is not easy to divvy up $ 20 billion. Perhaps no one in America knows this better than Kenneth R. Selznick." Grunwald also points out that BP hosted at least 53 fundraising parties for lawmakers and candidates in the wake of the oil spill, four of them since the explosion. Lobbyists typically represent multiple clients, and it's not clear how many of the events were intended to advance BP's interests. Click here for more.

– Kent Wells, BP's senior vice president in charge of the Gulf oil spill cleanup, was grilled by federal investigators yesterday about the company's history of safety problems in the region, the New York Times reports. Asked who had final responsibility for the accident, Wells said, "I don't think it's fair to say. I think it's fair to say that there have been a lot of problems over the last 25 years or so in the Gulf of Mexico." Investigators also want to know why it took BP so long to build the device that was supposed to stop the spill, the Houston Chronicle reports. BP has a formidable team of lobbyists in Washington to help it with the spill crisis, the Times notes.

– The live video of BP's latest attempt to contain the oil in the Gulf of Mexico didn't help the company's cause today, reports the New York Times. The live video, which will be available for at least 24 hours, doesn't capture much of what's happening, notes the Times, but it will at least show the company's latest attempt to curtail the spill, the so-called "top kill." It involves pumping mud into the venting pipe, and it's not clear whether that will work.

– Those receiving payments from BP in the wake of the Gulf oil spill will have to pay up on their taxes, the IRS announced today. Under current law, the payments are taxable—just as wages would have been, the IRS said. The development comes as new BP chief executive Bob Dudley made his first public appearance since the spill, notes the Times-Picayune.

– BP's corporate code of conduct says the company will not make political contributions, "whether in cash or in kind, anywhere in the world," the Washington Post reports. But in the wake of the Gulf oil spill, the company has donated $4,300 to the Marine Spill Response Corp, a group that has spent tens of millions of dollars in the past 20 years to provide equipment and personnel in the event of an offshore spill.

– As the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico threatens to become one of the biggest in history, there's a lot of finger-pointing going on—between BP, the government, environmentalists, and others. The New York Times takes a look at some of the key players: BP CEO Tony Hayward: He's in charge of the company's response to the spill, and he's got a lot of explaining to do. President Obama: He's going to ask Congress to make BP pay for the cleanup, and he's going to ask the Justice Department to make BP pay for the damage to the environment and, yes, the economy. Congress: The House today passed a bill that would make BP pay for the cleanup, and it's expected to easily pass the Senate.

– The New York Times today takes a look at the "incalculable" cost of the Gulf oil spill and at the " misleading numbers game" playing out between BP and the feds. BP has told the feds that it will be able to capture most of the oil, but the Times reports that the company has only been able to skim or burn about 60% of the amount it says it will be able to remove from the Gulf in a day.

– The live video feed from BP's latest attempt to contain the oil in the Gulf of Mexico was "as frenetic as the final minutes of a close soccer match and as slow as a space walk," reports the Los Angeles Times. The company removed the containment cap that had been capturing some of the oil and planned to replace it with a more powerful one. The plan is to lower three ships over the well and overwhelm it with mud. The live video feed is expected to continue for at least 24 hours, notes the New York Times.

– BP finally installed a new cap on its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico today, but the plan has been delayed until at least Wednesday as the company tries to make sure it has everything in place to plug the well permanently. The live video feed of BP's latest attempt to control the spill, which the Los Angeles Times describes as "increasinglyzada," is expected to show the company's engineers making progress over the next 24 hours.

– SpongeBob SquarePants and his friends in Bikini Bottom have a message for the BP contractors, cleanup crews, and news media that have descended on this small beach town where oil washes up almost daily, reports the Federal Eye. "We want BP contractors, cleanup crews, and news media to know that the people of Grand Isle and the entire Gulf Coast are with them," the cartoon characters say in an altered version of a photo they took last week. "We want the oil to stay out of Grand Isle. We want the oil to stay out of Louisiana. We want the oil to stay out of Bikini Bottom." Click here for more.

– BP and the US government have agreed to keep the company's latest attempt to contain the Gulf oil spill open for at least 24 more hours. The plan is to pump mud into the well to plug it, a procedure known as a "static kill" that could take up to a week, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. The news comes as Exxon, Chevron, BP, and Halliburton announced a $1 billion joint project to design, manufacture, and store equipment needed to respond to an oil spill in the Gulf.
– BP has apologized and promised to investigate after a blogger discovered that the oil giant's official photos appear to have been altered using photo editing software, the AP reports.

– The Coast Guard has ordered BP to evacuate the area surrounding its ruptured oil well in the Gulf of Mexico ahead of Tropical Storm Bonnie, reports the Times-Picayune of New Orleans. The last of the workers will be out of the area by tomorrow morning. The storm is expected to make landfall in Louisiana late today or early tomorrow, notes the Washington Post.

– Chemical dispersants used in the Gulf of Mexico to break up the Deepwater Horizon oil spill have been found in Michigan waters, but the FDA says they don't appear to threaten the safety of seafood in the affected waters, the Detroit Free Press reports. The Obama administration has told Congress that three-quarters of the oil leaking into the Gulf is contained, with the rest either evaporated, skimmed, collected, burned off, dispersed, or dissolved.

– BP's board is expected to name Robert Dudley as the company's new CEO today, in a move that will make him the first American to head the company, the New York Times reports. Dudley, currently the company's chief operating officer, will take over for CEO Tony Hayward, who will step down at the end of the month. The choice of Dudley, who grew up in Mississippi, is surprising given the company's recent troubles, the Times notes.

– The plan is to pump mud into the gushing well to douse it in mud and cement, a procedure known as a "static kill" that could take up to three days, reports the New York Times. The live video feed will be watched by a live camera, but it's not clear whether BP will be able to withstand the pressure of the mud and cement, notes the Washington Post.

– BP finished pumping cement into the blown-out Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico today as part of its efforts to permanently plug the source of the nation's worst oil spill, the company said. Engineers started cementing the operation at 10:15am local time, the New York Times reports. The procedure to pump heavy mud into the well has succeeded in plugging it, officials said yesterday, and President Obama warned that the threat from the damaged Macondo well will not be eliminated until it is killed.

– The gooey oil fouling the Gulf of Mexico is on its way to the Gulf Coast, where it will take at least a month to clean up the mess, the New York Times reports. The Coast Guard has begun work on a device to direct mud and oil into the Gulf, but it could take as long as three months to get it in place. The first thing to do is suck up the huge amount of oil that's already in the Gulf. Once it's in place, the Coast Guard plans to suck up as much as 100,000 barrels a day—enough to fill three Olympic-size swimming pools—from the mouth of the Mississippi. The amount of oil coming out of the ruptured well is expected to be far higher than the current estimate of 5,000 barrels a day, the Times notes. In the meantime, the gooey stuff is washing ashore in Louisiana.

– TransOcean fired off a scathing letter to BP yesterday, accusing the oil giant of hoarding information and test results related to the Deepwater Horizon blowout, the Los Angeles Times reports. TransOcean fired off a scathing letter to BP yesterday, accusing the oil giant of hoarding information and test results related to the Deepwater Horizon blowout that killed 11 people and caused America's worst oil spill. BP fired back, accusing TransOcean of "an outrageous and desperate attempt to contain information about the spill." TransOcean fired back, accusing BP of hoarding information and test results related to the Deepwater Horizon blowout, which killed 11 people and caused America's worst oil spill. TransOcean fired off a scathing letter accusing BP of hoarding information and test results related to the Deepwater Horizon blowout, which killed 11 people and caused America's worst oil spill. BP and TransOcean are in an increasingly bitter battle over what went wrong on April 20 to trigger America's worst oil spill. The conflict flared yesterday when TransOcean fired off a scathing letter accusing BP of hoarding information and test results related to the Deepwater Horizon blowout.

– The blowout preventer that was supposed to have cut off the flow of oil from the Deepwater Horizon well didn’t work properly, BP’s senior vice president told a federal panel investigating the disaster yesterday. The blowout preventer, which is supposed to shut off the flow of oil if something goes wrong, wasn’t properly installed, the New York Times reports. The panel also cited a 2003 letter from the federal Minerals Management Service criticizing BP’s “incomplete planning, poor communication, insufficient knowledge or training, and a lack of effective supervision” in its investigation of the disaster.

– BP says it has spent more than $5 million a week on advertising since the Gulf oil spill—more than three times the amount it spent on ads during the same period last year, reports the Washington Post. The company told a House committee today that it spent a total of 93 million dollars on ads between April and July.

– BP's internal report on the Gulf oil spill lays much of the blame for the mess on the company's equipment, the New York Times reports. The report, which was obtained by the Times through a Freedom of Information Act request, says the blowout preventer wasn't working properly, and that the blowout preventer itself wasn't working at all. The report also notes that BP equipment on the wellhead wasn't working properly, and that the blowout preventer itself wasn't working at all. BP's chief executive, Tony Hayward, said today that the company is working to contain the spill and make sure it doesn't happen again, the AP reports.

– The results of BP's internal investigation into the Deepwater Horizon oil spill are in, and they show no sign that the company cut corners to save money, the investigation's chief investigator tells the New York Times. "My view is that we did n't see any indications that support that," said Mark Bly. The investigation also found no evidence that BP cut corners to save money on the drilling operation that ruptured the well, or on the equipment that was supposed to be plugged. The report, which BP says will help the company avoid future mistakes, was released this week.

– A federal judge has ordered BP to hold off on drilling the well responsible for the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico until it can determine whether the blowout preventer was properly installed, the AP reports. The Justice Department is reviewing the blowout preventer's design and other aspects of BP's drilling operation in the wake of the spill. The New Orleans Times-Picayune reports that the blowout preventer has been on the market for more than a year.

– BP has agreed to join forces with Exxon, Chevron, Royal Dutch Shell, and ConocoPhillips in the event of an oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New York Times reports. The oil giant will spend $1 billion to create equipment and train teams in the event of a major spill. The other four companies said they would spend the same amount on training and equipment. The agreement, which still needs to be finalized, is part of an effort by the oil companies to work together in the event of a major spill.

– New BP CEO Bob Dudley has shaken up the company's senior leadership in the wake of the Gulf oil spill. He has ousted the company's chief of exploration and production and divided his responsibilities among three other BP executives, the Wall Street Journal reports. The shake-up is part of Dudley's plan to make the company more effective in the wake of the spill, the New York Times notes.

– Thad W. Allen can finally retire now. The Miami Herald reports that the NBA's Miami Heat will play the Houston Rockets in the second game of a second-round playoff series on Saturday night. The game will be held at the AmericanAirlines Arena in Miami.

– The Obama administration's handling of the Gulf oil spill has been marked by confusion and a lack of leadership, according to preliminary reports from the National Commission on the BP Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill and Offshore Drilling. The preliminary reports say the administration created the impression that it was either "not fully competent" or "not fully candid with the American people about the scope of the problem," the Los Angeles Times reports.

– The New York Times has a piece today on President Obama's decision to allow more drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, and it's drawing attention for two reasons: First, it's a sign that the White House is serious about climate change, and second, it's part of a pattern of behavior that's out of step with the rest of the country. The Times notes that in recent weeks, Obama has been traveling the country to talk about the issue, including a trip to a battery factory in North Carolina in April.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil leaking into the Gulf of Mexico ran into technical obstacles over the weekend that increased the likelihood of a prolonged battle to stop the leak, reports the Los Angeles Times. BP's effort to contain the oil leaking into the Gulf of Mexico ran into technical obstacles over the weekend that increased the likelihood of a prolonged battle to stop the leak. BP's effort to contain the oil leaking into the Gulf of Mexico ran into technical obstacles over the weekend that increased the likelihood of a prolonged battle to stop the leak.

– As the scope of the Haiti earthquake becomes clear, one thing is becoming clear: The toll is likely to be in the tens of thousands, reports the New York Times. The country's president-elect, Jean-Max Bellerive, says the toll could be in the thousands. "It could be in the tens of thousands," he told reporters at a news conference at the Port-au-Prince airport. "I'm sure it will be in the thousands." The AP has more on Bellerive and the country's devastated infrastructure.

– It's that time of the year again to recognize and honor the men and women who have fought and died in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. And to recognize the bravery and sacrifice of the men and women who have served and died in Iraq and Afghanistan.

– It's that time of the year again to recognize and honor the men and women who have fought and died in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. And to recognize the bravery and sacrifice of the men and women who have served and died in Iraq and Afghanistan.

– As the scope of the Haiti disaster becomes clear, one thing is becoming clear: The nation's infrastructure is in such bad shape that it could take years to rebuild, reports the New York Times. The Haitian government has been unable to control the flow of aid and has been unable to control the looting that has plagued the capital of Port-au-Prince. The UN has asked for help from the international community, and it is sending an additional 3,500 troops to the country, reports the BBC. The US is sending up to 1,000 Marines to help distribute aid.

– As the scope of the Haiti disaster becomes clear, one thing is becoming clear: The toll is going to be a lot higher than previously thought. The UN now estimates at least 200,000 have died in the devastating quake, and it expects that to rise to at least 300,000, reports the New York Times. The Haitian government has been overwhelmed by the response to the disaster, and it has been unable to control violence that has plagued the country in the wake of the quake. The latest: The US military has raised the number of American troops in Haiti from 10,000 to 20,000, reports the BBC, and the US military says it is sending two more warships to the island to help distribute aid. The British government has announced that it is sending two planes to Haiti to deliver aid to the country. The AP has the latest on the situation in Port-au-Prince. Simon Cowell has organized a charity single to raise funds for the Haiti relief effort, which will include a cover of REM's "Everybody Hurts" by Rod Stewart, Leona Lewis, JLS, and Michael Buble.

– It's that time of the year again to recognize and honor the men and women who have fought and died in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. And to recognize the bravery and sacrifice of the men and women who have served and died in Iraq and Afghanistan.
